alert.note: Alert for Coos; Grafton (New Hampshire) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued July 18 at 8:00PM EDT until July 18 at 11:00PM EDT by NWS Gray/Portland
info.description: The National Weather Service in Gray has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Southwestern Coos County in northern New Hampshire... Northeastern Grafton County in northern New Hampshire... * Until 1100 PM EDT. * At 800 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 1 to 3 inches in 1 hour. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Some areas in the warning have already seen heavy rain earlier today. HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Berlin, Littleton, Lancaster, Bethlehem, Lincoln, Franconia, Woodstock, Stratford, Carroll and Jefferson. This includes the following highways... Interstate 93 between mile markers 90 and 115. This includes the following Rec locations... Franconia Notch, Kilkenny Ridge Trail, Mount Moosilauke, Cannon Mountain, North Twin Mountain, Franconia Ridge, Mount Jefferson, Mount Eisenhower, Mount Lafayette, Mount Garfield, AMC Highland Center, AMC Greenleaf Hut, AMC Lonesome Lake Hut, AMC Galehead Hut, AMC Zealand Falls Hut, AMC Mizpah Spring Hut, Mount Cabot, South Pond Recreation Area, Carr Mountain, Stinson Mountain, Elbow Pond Recreation Area, South Kinsman Mountain, Mount Flume, Mount Liberty, South Twin Mountain, Mount Bond, Mount Carrigan, Mount Willey, Mount Tom, Mount Field, Mount Jackson, Ripley Falls and Mount Osceola. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...1-3 INCHES IN 1 HOUR
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
